file_content.text: The newest reports indicate that the toxins are seeping into the water table. Ha! Nothing will purify that ruin now.
My sensors picked it up the moment you opened the containers. Well done.
Because of you, Taris ChemWorks remains as the Empire intended--a deadly, chemical-burned ruin.
Speaking of, I should treat you for contamination. I'd hate for you to get ill from the exposure.
Chaos, sabotage and destruction. It'll do.
All in a day's work.
It's good to enjoy your work.
I only regret not being able to see their faces when the Republic learns of the contamination.
What do I do if your decontamination doesn't work?
And if I get sick...?
Well, in the slim chance that your lungs begin to liquefy--I can take care of you.
After all, it's important to protect the Empire's talented assets.
What a waste of my time.
I'm sorry you don't approve, but you've been valuable help. The Republic won't recover from the blow you've dealt them.
The longer you take, the more time those Republic fools have to find and destroy those chemicals.
My lord, please excuse the mess. I don't get many visitors in the lab.
You gave me a fright. I thought you were here for the environmental reports.
I'm sorry, we don't get many visitors to the lab. Most people avoid us.
Still, I'm glad you stopped by. The Republic's efforts to clean and recolonize Taris are accelerating, but I've found a way to stop them.
I just need someone to release the dangerous toxins inside a crumbling, mephitic ruin.
Most of Taris is a ruin. Be more specific.
What crumbling ruin?
The Taris ChemWorks--a shuddering remnant of its past, filled with leaking stockpiles of poisonous waste.
Your accent--you don't sound Imperial.
You're not from the Empire....
The Empire welcomed me when the Republic accused me of war crimes--but my past isn't important. Taris's past is.
Before the Empire bombarded Taris, the ChemWorks was a prosperous factory full of deadly chemicals. Those chemicals are still there.
The Republic can't possibly make this place livable.
Recolonize Taris? Absurd.
You'd be surprised; they've already established water purification plants. However--the Taris ChemWorks will be their undoing.
Before Taris's destruction, the ChemWorks produced all manner of deadly chemicals, which still remain.
The Republic burned off most of the pollutants, but they missed the barrels of 3-5-7 trichloroheptane, a beautifully lethal poison.
Do we know why the Republic missed them?
How'd that happen?
The factory used to be a maze of secure storage depots. Without a proper inventory, it's understandable.
I'm not familiar with that particular chemical.
Trichloro-what?
Trichloroheptane. Among other things, it's a virulent poison that forms an acidic mist when exposed to air. It would quickly contaminate the entire area.
I'm waiting for my part.
Exactly. If the factory were unguarded, I could take care of it myself.
Unfortunately, the Republic knows the ChemWorks is central to Taris's reclamation. They stationed a squad of commandos there.
If you can force your way in and break open the chemical containers, the resulting corrosive fog will poison the soil for a century.
The Republic has none who can oppose me.
Simple enough.
The weak minds of the Republic are no obstacle to me.
Simple enough.
You're lucky I came along when I did.
Simple enough.
Infiltration and sabotage are my stock and trade.
Simple enough.
If you succeed, you'll cripple the Republic's cleanup efforts. I wish you luck.
Foiling the Republic is one thing. You want to ruin a planet.
Is all that really necessary?
It's not permanent damage, strictly speaking. Besides, the faster the Republic gives up, the fewer of us need to die.
The ruins of the ChemWorks are located near the Republic's outposts.
Move quickly. If the Republic figures out what chemicals we're looking for, they'll destroy them first.
Find another. [Refuse quest]
You'll regret not helping me, just as the Republic shall regret opposing me.
Republic fools. Soon they'll regret ever having opposed me.
